ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: how to program robots using ROS. Creating tensorflow NN and implementing them in robotics features. Improving Keras models by modifying training parameters. camera image projection and the corresponding matrix math. sensors that help automate robots. A lot of interesting applications of AI in robotics.
I learned about various machine learning algorithms at both a high and low level. Also, I was able to apply my knowledge through the final project and problem sets.

I learned how to work with the Robot Operating System (ROS), many cutting-edge techniques in the fields of robotics / machine learning, and how to contribute effectively in the context of a robotics team project.
I understood more about human robot social interaction and reinforcement learning.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Marynel explains a lot of really complex mathematical concepts clearly and lectures well. There's also a lot of freedom with the final project so you can actually build something really cool that you are proud of! The grading is super clear and fair. 
Weaknesses: Sometimes the content just goes so fast especially if you don't have a strong background in linear algebra. She would sometimes go through slides and slides of mathematical proofs and I just wouldn't understand half of it and just hope to screenshot the slides and understand later.
The class was fun and challenging but if you don't have a high enough math background it makes the lectures less engaging and a bit confusing.

The strengths of the course are that Dr. Vasquez is an exceptional instructor and the lectures are always beautifully put together. The content is fascinating, well-researched, and highly relevant to current industry tools. The speakers are great and so are the paper presentations / demos. An issue with the grading system that I am not really sure how to resolve is that members of the final group project may focus on their individual deliverables, enhancing their own grade while leaving more work for others to do in the group. The leaderboard extra-credit activity for assignment #2 is a particularly relevant example, especially since it was due in close proximity to the milestone.
Some of the grading policies seem a bit unclear to me. More clear instructions and evaluation for homework would be appreciated

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
It is a really interesting class if you are interested in robotics or AI. I would say I learned I probably don't want to work in robotics, but that's also really helpful and important information. 
The workload was not too terrible, but the psets are DIFFICULT. There aren't many which is why I say the workload is pretty comparable, but they were really difficult for me to wrap my head around. I would take like 3 hours to write just a few lines of code because I had to spend a lot of time understanding the math. Coming with no background in linear algebra definitely made it more difficult, but not impossible. I would also recommend taking it with friends because you can't do the homework all alone and the project would be more fun with people you know and like.
Yes, I would recommend this course to students who want to learn more about machine learning and/or robotics

I would recommend this course to any student that wants to do something cool with robots, is willing to dig deep into a lot of robotics / mathematics / computer science, cares about human-computer interaction, and has a lot of extra time that semester.
Yes, the course covers a wide breadth of interesting topics
